1.content:
You strap the small dagger and leather pouch of gold to your belt, and bid your parents farewell one last time, before mounting your chestnut mare that you raised from a foal. Your mother is trying to hold back tears, of joy or sorrow, you cannot tell. Your father just gives you a proud smile, and they both wave goodbye as you ride away across the property line of your family's farm towards the capital.

Since the age o f five, you've always wanted to join the ranks of the Heroes. Your parents would tell you stories of the most famous Heroes from when they were your age, and their mighty and noble deeds. Slaying monsters, rescuing those in danger and distress, battling evil overlords who sought to enslave the land. Even as a child, you knew you wanted to be one of them. Today, you are finally of age to set out on your own, and fulfill your lifelong dream.

For three days, you ride West across fields and through forests until you reach the capital gates. Having grown up on a humble farm, you can't help but marvel at the sights of the magnificent city as your horse clops along through the cobblestone streets, not even noticing the stares and a few sneers you receive from the nobles dressed in their satin and velvet outfits.

You find yourself at the entrance to the Hero's Academy, where all Heroes train before officially joining the Guild. You hitch your horse by the entrance and enter a grand hall, the walls lined with tapestries bearing the Guild's insignia. At the end of the hall is a large desk of polished wood, a female elf sitting behind it, surrounded by parchment and writing quills. As you approached she looks up and says "May I help you?"

"I wish to enroll at the academy." You state proudly. The elf sighs before reaching under the desk and heaving up a massive ledger bound in leather and emblazoned with the Guild's symbol. "Name?" "Taren Feldrake." "Preferred class?"

(Before we go any further, is your character male or female? Also after selecting your class and sub-class, don't bother describing your time spent at the academy, and just skip ahead to when you graduate. This story is supposed to focus on Heroes, not Heroes-in-training.)

1133.content:
"I want to be a Paladin," you said.

"Ah," the elf said. "Defender of Righteousness, Keeper of the Faith, and, for the most part, Lawful Good...... actually, scratch that last piece of crap - it's hard to find someone that's strictly Lawful Good. Better off just sticking with Good Enough."

"Is it really that hard to be Lawful Good?" you asked.

"Well, if you end up serving a Lawful Evil king, you'll come to a point where you'll have to pick between Lawful and Good," the elf said. "Luckily, the requirements for being a Paladin are much easier than they used to be. Actually, a lot of things are easier. The whole alignment thing practically got chucked out the window a couple of decades ago, allowing for bards and barbarians to be Lawful, druids to be one of the corners on the square, paladins and clerics to be Chaotic, and all of the other classes too. Really opened the field for those who previously didn't meet the stricter requirements. Also, things change more often all over."

"So, things change?" you ask.

"About every six months, someone learns something new about the class," the elf said. "Used to be that only Necromancers and paladins that broke their oath could summon the undead. These days, there's of course Necromancers, Oathbreakers, who are Evil by the way, Death Domain Clerics, who can be Neutral or Good by the way, Circle of Spores Druids, they need to lay off those mushrooms as those make their breath stink, Eldritch Knights, Arcane Trickster rogues, wizards in general, and, our most recent addition, Oath of Death Paladin."

"Oath of Death?" you ask.

"It was started by some reformed Oathbreakers who found out that they still had those Necromancy-type spells, and other such features, despite renouncing the ways of Evil," the elf said. "They can even get their zombies and skeletons to do more than just be arrow fodder and trap bait - cooking, cleaning, general servant duty, night watch, carry loot, and be better at scouting out for traps and ambushes. They can even speak to them as if they were living."

"Interesting," you said.

"Also, if you don't have it, you get Darkvision, and if you already got it, an improved version," the elf said.

"Useful," you said.

"Alright," the elf said. "Now, let's look at your options. There's a lot, so if none of the ones I mention now interest you, let me know and we'll go to the next part of the list."

"Alright," you said.

The elf nodded. "First up, Oath of Death - Necromancy-based spells, Darkvision, Improved undead summons, and you're terrifying to your foes, plus you get access to this black armor that lets you hide in dark places." A black suit of armor showed up on the wall.

"Nice," you say.

"Next is Oath of Light," the elf continued. "Improved healing spells, protective spells, undead are weak against you, you Inspire people, and you get access to this golden armor that acts as a light source." A shiny suit of armor appeared.

"A little bright," you said.

"It's not real good for stealthy things," the elf said. "Oath of Water - communicate with water-based creatures, summon a water elemental, varies between a relatively minor up to a very powerful one, depending on your level and control, ability to swim very well, and breath underwater, plus this blue armor, which lets you get on the good side of undersea folks easier." A blue suit of armor showed up.

"Cool," you said.

"If you say to," the elf said. "Next up, Oath of Fire. Fire-based spells, summon a fire-based being, which could include fire-breathing dragons, resistance and later immunity to fire, and this red suit of armor, which lets you talk to fire-based creatures easier." A red suit of armor showed up.

"Hot," you said, feeling the heat radiating from it.

"Whatever you say," the elf said. "So, one of these, or do I go to the next section of the List?"

Your time at the Academy had been fun. You learned the use of various weapons, armor, shield, horseback riding, mounted combat, and how to use your Paladin spells. Granted, summoning Jim, Jeb, and Juanita had been scary the first time you did it, especially as their bones came forth from the ground, but after a while, you got used to it. They came in handy when you forgot to get certain weapons from the training room, or as sparing partners. Even some of the cleric-types you'd befriended had to admit that the trio had their use, as they'd often ask you for help in training their abilities that repealed undead. Granted, Jim, Jeb, and Juanita didn't like it, but you'd been smart enough to ask them to help out, and let the one that did help out have the day off, and not need to do as you said, which made the trio a bit more willing in that regard. That being said, you were smart enough not to force them into doing something they didn't want to do. Teachers had drilled in that lesson quite clearly. An upset summon could easily figure out a means in which to let the one that summoned them get into serious trouble and potentially get hurt or die.

But, your time at the Academy was now over. Now was the part where you had to get a Quest, take a job, or somehow earn your money, and in general, prove that you were indeed a Hero! Now it was just a matter of what kind of work you'd be willing to do. Luckily, there was always a job somewhere. In fact, the tavern always had something to be offered, or so you'd heard. There was usually a bounty or two, a small quest posted, someone looking for a party, or a party looking for someone to join them.

As you entered the tavern, you were mildly surprised at how quickly your eyes adjusted within five seconds to the dimmer light of the interior, compared to the usual thirty-sixty seconds it used to take. For a moment, things quieted, as folks started to look at you, making you feel nervous.

Then, you heard it.

"Move rookie!" said a low deep voice.

You turned, and found yourself looking at a scarred half-orc barbarian.

"Either you'll move or I'll rip your arm off and beat you with it," the half-orc barbarian said. "That black armor don't scare me, not when I've seen things that will make you shit in it!"

You decided to move, and let the half-orc through. You didn't feel like getting yourself tossed out for fighting.

"Weakling," he said, as he shoved you to one side, despite you having already moved for him.

"What a jerk," you mutter, as you head towards the notice board. Much to your surprise, the half-orc was on it, in the form of a Wanted notice, for the unlawful, and illegal, killing of an innocent dragon. The price on his head was over fifty thousand gold.

You turned your head, to look at the half-orc. This could be your start to your path of being a Hero.

You're about to mutter the words needed to summon Jim Jeb, and Juanita, in order to give you some help, when you heard someone clear their throat, loudly.

You glance next to you, and see one of those feline types, a female one, if you know your information correctly.

"Don't even think about it," they muttered. "He'd throw his ax and behead you before you got one syllable out." She tapped the lower part of the poster.

You looked at it. In addition to the dragon, there was over two dozen other murders and illegal deaths on this guy's hands, with a warning that only experienced adventurers should try to take him on.

"What about you?" you asked. "Could you take him?"

"Maybe, but it would be a close thing," she said. "Also, I have my own issues with the Law." She tapped on another poster.

You looked at it, and on the poster indicated was an image of the cat lady, who had a price for thirty thousand gold, for numerous thefts.

"I'm surprised that the guards here haven't arrested you," you said.

"I'm smart enough to behave myself in this town," the cat lady said. "As for him, no guard would dare to try and capture him."

"What if we worked together to do it?" you asked. "We bring him in, pay off your debt, and split what's left."

"Hmm, tempting," she said.

11331113.content:
She was about to reply when suddenly, her eyes widened. She then shoved you, and ducked her head, as an ax smashed through the wall, where both of your heads would have been.

"So, you two think that you can take me on," the half-orc said. He held out his arm. The ax smashed its way back into the tavern, and flew to the half-orc's hand. "I don't think so."

"Guess that story's true," the cat lady said. She whipped out a dagger, and threw it into the barbarian's gut.

The half-orc growled. "I'll skin you alive for that!" He pulled out the dagger and threw it at them.

The cat lady held out her hand, catching the dagger the hard way. "Run!"

You ran out the door, the cat lady just behind you, and, from what you could hear, the half-orc behind her.

You looked back at her, and saw her pull the dagger out of her hand, blood coming out. "You're bleeding!"

"I'll live!" she said. "Keep running!"

You grab her injured hand and, as you ran, you uttered the healing words you'd been taught. A bright light enveloped both of your respective hands.

"Uh, thanks," she said. "Mind letting go? Got a plan!"

"Mind sharing?"

"Head down that alley, summon your skeletons, and have them grab him when he gets down it," she said.

"And you?" you ask.

"You'll have to trust me on that part," she said. "Now go!" That was when she sped past you.

"Guess she was holding back," you muttered. You then ran down the alley, which had a lot of shadow, so your armor allowed you to hide for a moment. You managed to mutter the words to summon Jim, Jeb, and Juanita, just as the half-orc came into the alley as well.

"I know you're here," he said. "I can smell you."

"Grab him and keep him from moving," you commanded.

The three skeletons rushed forward, to do your bidding.

The half-orc threw his ax, chopping Jim in half.

You gasp in shock for a moment. Then chuckled as Jim reformed, and kept running towards the barbarian.

Soon, all three had grabbed a hold of the half-orc, pinning his arms and legs. But, the half-orc kept fighting.

That was when it happened. The half-orc started to stiffen. "What?! Paralysis? How?"

You heard the chuckle. You looked up to the rooftop to see the cat lady playing with her dagger.

"You're not the only one with tricks up their sleeves," she said. She took out a vial and shook it. "Kind of useful when one wants to slip past a guard. In your case, placed it on my dagger before I threw it."

You looked at her. "What about you?"

She chuckled. "When you use something like that, make sure to have an antidote. I'm good." She jumped from the rooftop. "Let's take him to the guard house. They can contact the Dragon Lords, so that he can be picked up to be executed." She then got rope out of her pack.

"Thanks for the help," you said. "I owe you one."

The cat lady chuckled. "Might be the other way around. You healing my hand made it easier for me to get my antidote to stave off my own paralysis."

"Thanks anyways," you said. "I'm Cedric."

"Cloud is my name," the cat lady said.

You offer your hand, and she shook it.

"Now, come on," Cloud said. "Fifty thousand gold isn't just going to swap places with him if we jabber all day."

"Right." You look at Jim, Jeb, and Juanita. "You three, pick him up and carry him."

The skeletons nodded, and pick him up, probably a little more roughly than you'd prefer, but you couldn't really blame them - he'd almost killed you.



Soon enough, you got to a guard station with your package, which was still struggling. You pounded on the door. "Got a Bounty to turn in here!"

A moment later, the Head Guard opened the door's viewport. "I see. Been wanting them for some time. Give me a moment."

You heard the door unlock, and watched it open up.

"How'd you get them," they asked.

"I had some help," you said.

"Your skeletons that good?" the guard asked.

"No, I had some help from -" You looked and saw that.....

113311133.content:
Much to your surprise, Cloud was already inside the station, getting a bottle out of a desk.

"Need a bit of a drink after that capture, Sir," she said.

The head guard turned his head, and laughed. "Was Crog that tough that you needed help from a rookie?"

"Not really," Cloud said, pouring a drink. "To be fair, Cedric tried to rope me into the job and splitting the reward between us, when Crog decided that he wanted our heads."

"I see," the guard said. "In that case -" he looked at you. "How do you want your eighty thousand gold? All of it now, or some upfront with a receipt for the rest?"

"Wait, isn't Crog worth fifty?" you asked.

"You forget?" Cloud asked. "I'm worth thirty."

"But, I wasn't planning to turn you in," you said.

Cloud sipped on her drink. "No, but it makes for a better story, both for yourself, and for me, for when I eventually escape from my cell." She looked at the head guard. "The usual cell?"

"Do you want the one where the door doesn't lock quite right, or the one with the window you can squeeze out of?" the head guard asked.

"Prefer the one with the bad door," Cloud said. "I don't fancy scrapping off my fur again. Took three weeks to grow right."

"Could lose a little weight," the head guard said, quietly.

"I heard that," said Cloud.

"Um, what's going on?" you ask.

"Publicly, I'm a wanted thief," said Cloud. "Confidentially, I work for the Guard. My job is to infiltrate dangerous groups, and bring them down from within."

You looked over at Crog, who looked like he was paying attention. "What about him?"

Cloud chuckled. "Him? Where he's going, not even the most powerful necromancer could raise him." She set her glass down. "Dragons execute murders of our size by eating them."

Crog growled as he heard the news. "I'll get you for this."

"Good luck," said Cloud. "By this time tomorrow, the dragons will be here to collect you. After that, you'll be on your way to becoming dragon shit, among other things."

"So, what about me?" you asked.

"You'll get the money, and the usual rewards that come for being a Hero," said Cloud. "Discounts at various stores, women wanting to have your baby, folks buying you drinks, and a few other things. Might even have a dragon fancy you."

You had to chuckle at this. "That's quite the reward."

"Not bad, for a rookie fresh from the academy," said Cloud.

You decided to look at the Notice board for a simple quest, or perhaps one that had a low amount of pay. With eighty thousand gold, you could afford to be picky. Then again, getting better weapons wouldn't hurt your chances either, same with getting potions and a few other things.

As you looked it over, noticing that there was a bakery dealing with a large rat issue, something caught your attention. Standing next to you, also staring at the Notice board, was one of the Yuan-Ti, in the getup of a cultist. However, the other thing that also caught your attention was a poster that had the snakeman's image upon it. He was worth ten thousand gold. Alive.

"Three criminals in one day?" they said quietly. "Don't push your luck. Besides, you might be of use, according to our mutual friend, Cloud."

That was when you saw it. A coin-sized amulet that quickly disappeared up the sleeve of the Yuan-Ti's cloak. An amulet carried by the City Guards.

"What do you want?" you asked.

"The Guard could use you as an Extractor," the Yuan-Ti said. "Sometimes it's hard to get one of us out of whatever group we've infiltrated, especially since using the Guard might bring about the wrong kind of attention. A Bounty Hunter on the other hand, one with no Official connections to the Guard beyond using them as a place to exchange criminals for receipts, that's a different matter."

"You want to use me to get your people out of trouble, by turning them in as if they were criminals with a price on their heads?" you ask.

The snakeman nodded. "That's about the size of it. Of course, most won't bring in as high a price as Cloud, but you're still looking at a few thousand gold apiece. Of course, it's only good if we're alive, as per the Request."

"I understand," you said.

"Good," the Yuan-Ti said. "Contact you later. By the way, the antidote for the poison is in your side pocket."

"What poison?" you asked.

"This!"

That was when he sprayed venom into your eyes, all but blinding you, causing you to blunder into a table. As you tried to wash your eyes out with the contents of your drink, you fished around in your pocket, grabbing a bottle. You pulled it out, uncorked it, and drank the contents. Your eyes recovered in a few seconds afterwards. You looked around, and saw that the Yuan-Ti was gone, and that everyone else was looking at you.

You chuckled nervously. "I don't think he wanted me to bring him in."

This caused the rest of the tavern to laugh out loud, and soon the drinks resumed flowing. Some even landed in front of you, and more than a few more experienced adventurers slapped your back.

"Can't get them all!" one said.

"There's always that one that gets away!" said another.

"At least it wasn't a goblin like yours!" the first said.

"You're one to talk," the second said. "There's still kobold who laugh about the fact that you couldn't catch one of them in broad daylight!"

"Oh really!" That was when the first jumped over the table, and started a wrestling match with the second. "You're the one that slept with a succubus!"

"Better that than a hag!"

You moved over to the counter as the two continued to wrestle. "What a day." You looked at the owner of the place. "A room for the night?"

He nodded, indicated payment, you gave him some coins, and he gave you a key. "Room Eleven."

"Thanks," you said. You then went upstairs, to get some much needed rest.

"So, we'll be protecting a caravan," you said. "The pay looks good."

"Could use a few more," said Kragg. "The Ranus route is filled with bandits."

"Perhaps me and my friends could be of assistance."

You turned, and found yourself looking at a member of the turtlefolk race known as Tortles, who had turned their own chair a bit.

"Sorry, but I couldn't help but overhear, you're going on a trip that takes you along the Ranus route?" they asked.

"Yes," said Grildo. "Do you know the route well?"

"Not me personally, but Kosj grew up not too far from the area, and knows it fairly well," the tortle said.

You looked, and saw one of the lizardfolk, who was wearing a getup similar to that used by Druids. Then, there was the lionman, one of the Leonin, who wore the symbol of the goddess of healing upon their chestplate. Then there was a crowman, a Kenku, who was hunched over the table, working on something.

"Kosj, Druid of the Beasts, Xior, Cleric of Healing, but don't let that fool you if you upset him enough, Tinker the Tinkerer, and myself, Baka the Necromancer."

You widened your eyes a bit. There was potential for both magic and and physical capabilities here. Still, you couldn't help but wonder.... "Why would you be willing to travel with us?"

"We'll be heading along that way anyways," said Xior. "Been asked to deliver a package of rare herbs toa place that specializes in making improvements to healing potions and the like."

"Then there's the other three who'll throw in," Kosj said. "Konar the Duergar dwarf, who happens to be a Celestial Warlock, Lask the Kobold, a Monk of the Kensei way, and then there's Raza, the Goblin, who thinks he's an Assassin, but he's better at being a Thief."

"Bad Assassin, good Thief," Tinker said, in a female voice.

"Assassin?" you ask.

"Only if he's been paid to do the job," said Baka. "He's better at the stealing anyways."

"This won't be the usual party makeup, that's for sure," said Esmeralda.

There's even a few versions of the tale - one being that Folra stole something from Stabor, one being that Folra was promised to Stabor but she refused him, and a third being that Folra liked playing hard to get whenever Stabor wanted to mate with her, and that he'd have to catch her first. "Lots of that seems to happen," you said.

Most say no, but then the barkeep tells you that Ben is a frequent customer, and if he's not at the tavern he's probably at the Golden Rose. You'd never heard of the place, but the barkep gives you directions.

It had been a long day, and start to the night by the time you got back into the tavern. There'd been plenty of cheers about what you'd done, about how you'd beheaded one of the leading succubi of the group that had been killing people, and about your mighty fists knocking off demon skulls in a single blow. It took you a few drinks before you could leave and head upstairs to sleep. You were barely conscious of the fact that you had undressed before crawling into bed for sleep, and blowing out the candle.

Thus, it came as a shock when a hand gripped your mouth, and a blade touched your throat.

"Don't say a word," said a familiar voice.

Your eyes strained against the darkness, but without your armor, all you could see was a dark shape looming over you.

"Now, I've never given anyone an undeserved cut, so don't move unless I do it for you."

The blade moved from your throat, to just under your right ear, and the person moved their fingers. Then, the blade began to scrape down your face, going with the grain of what facial hair you did have.

"It's funny," the person said. "Among my kind, we see being shaved as some sort of humiliating punishment. Among yours, you see it as part of grooming."

You wanted to say something, but didn't feel like getting yourself cut. Besides, you had figured out who your self-appointed barber was - Cloud. Thus, you relaxed, somewhat.

"Good. I'm glad you know that it's a friend, and not an enemy who has a blade to your face," she said, as she moved her blade, and turned your head, to do the left side. "By your actions today, you've made a few enemies - by now, there's demons who have heard of your deeds. They will have placed a price upon your head."

Your eyes widened.

"Stay still," said Cloud. "That being said, there's quite a bit of good news - the Dragon Princess Askeera wishes to personally reward you. She's a powerful ally to have on your side. I would know - prevented someone from abducting one of her cousin's eggs a couple of years back." She shifted the blade to under your nose. "Of course, in order to keep my cover, she agreed to declare me a thief who'd stolen some valuable jewels from said cousin, and to give credence to said story, I was allowed to 'steal' s number of them." She then shaved under your lower lip. "In case you're wondering, I'm not quite sure what she'll reward you with. It could be a marriage proposal, some draconian abilities, money, give you a title, or to be one of your lovers." She then worked under your chin. "All of course have their uses. Money's always good, extra abilities make fights easier, titles are good to pass on to your children or other relatives, and having a lover is useful for unwinding. And, that's done." She removed her blade from your face. "How do you like it?"

You felt your face. "Smooth."

"Good," said Cloud. "I know its customary among single human males to shave their faces, and since you looked like you hadn't shaved for a couple of days, I thought that it would be a good idea to give you one, and teach you an important lesson at the same time."

"What would that be?" you asked, as you sat up.

"Make sure you check the room before you actually enter," said Cloud. "If you had sent in one of your skeleton buddies first, they would have spotted me for sure. After that, secure the windows and door, in order to reduce the odds of someone entering without your notice. Also, make sure that have at least one of your skeleton's on watch at all times. Again, they can wake you up, or make enough noise to wake you up as they delay an intruder."

"I see," you said. "Still, you could have just woken me up and told me this stuff in the morning. You didn't have to shave me yourself."

You looked, and saw that Rabgud was holding onto a kobold.

"I didn't notice him take it," you said, putting the pouch back into your robes.

"Not much of a druid if she can't see," said Roko.

"And I'm a rogue who can't sneak, just as you're a barbarian that's not that intimidating," Rabgud said, dropping the kobold. "Birchvene, meet Roko, Roko, meet Birchvene."

"If she can't spot a pickpocket, what good is she?" Roko asked.

"She can help us find what we're looking for," said Rabgud. "That's more valuable. Besides - let Thunder and Mirik, and a couple of the others worry about spotting thieves. I caught you."

"Point taken," said Roko.

You looked at the kobold. He was barely two feet tall. "This is our Barbarian?"

"Judge me by my size, do?" Roko asked. "Bad idea, unless you fancy losing your legs. Roko Legchopper is what my enemies call me."

"Right," said Rabgud. "And the rest?"

"In the inn, waiting on Cyan to show up," said Roko. "Innkeeper has a spot on the floor for you."

"Tell me that you guys got a good price," Rabgud said. "I remember the last place."

"Don't remind me," said Roko. "There's times I'm still finding straw and dried manure in my stuff."

You looked at Rabgud. "What does he mean by that?"

"Place wanted twenty gold apiece, just to sleep in the barn, and we're not talking about a nice warm, and relatively clean, one either," said Rabgud. "Last time we're ever doing a job in that town."

"You're telling me," said Roko. "This place is clean, good beds, good food, and the innkeeper's wife's not bad-looking either, and he doesn't mind. Of course, he's not too shabby either."

"Whom did you do?" Rabgud asked.

The little lizard grinned. "I ain't saying."

"Knowing you, the innkeeper," said Rabgud.

"Maybe," said Roko. "Still, come on. Lunch should be ready soon."


Soon enough, you came to an inn, the doorway of which, Rabgud had to crawl through.

You looked around. The place looked nice, and there was a table filled with the folks Rabgud had described. There was even an empty table next to it, with a sign that said "Reserved for Rabgud."

"Very thoughtful," the half-giant said, practically crawling to the table, before he sat up, sitting on the floor.

"Our innkeeper is very understanding about such things," said Roko, as he climbed up some distinctly ladder-like rungs, up to a high chair that would fit a smaller person. "He's a goblin. And the wife, she's a firbolg."

"Guess he likes bigger women," said Rabgud.

The feeling was, again, that of a Predator watching their Prey.

You looked over at Rabgud.

The half-giant gave you a smile. "Minor precaution. One always on lookout, even when resting in a place like this."

"Alright," you said.

"Uh, thank you," you said. You told them what you wanted.

The tabaxi looked at you, and chuckled. "You meet all sorts when you Adventure."

The next two that came in were an odd pair - one was a devil-like Tiefling, and the other was an angel-like Aasimar, who, unlike what would normally be expected, chatted like they were friends - actually, closer than that!

"This is going to be fun," said Zeed. "One's a Divine Soul Sorcerer, and the other is a warlock who gets their extra powers from a Devil - three gold says you can't guess which one is which."

"Aasimar is the Divine Soul, and the Tiefling is the one with a Fiend Patron," you said.

"And you just lost three gold," said Owag. "It's the other way around."

Your eyes bulged out. "Really?"

"Never expect the usual with us," said Teoz. "Pay Zeed."

You reluctantly take the coins out of your pouch, and hand them to the Aarakocra.

"Thank you," said Zeed. He waved at the pair. "Cain, Dano, good to have you with us."

The tiefling and aasimar sat down, and ordered their drinks, and soon began talking to Berov.

The next one that came in was a centaur, who had a pair of hand crossbows and a pair of shortswords within reach on him.

You looked at Owag. "Ranger, right?"

The tortle chuckled. "Roth's the bard - Collage of Lore."

The next few others surprised you - an Orc with a longbow, a Hobgoblin in the process of making some sort of potion, and Bugbear passing him herbs.

"Cronk the Hunter Ranger, Tovak the Alchemist Artificer, and Hovak the Circle of the Spores Druid," said Toez.

The trio nodded, and came up for their own drinks.

"You have some odd friends," you said.

"Wait until you see the other two," said Zeed.

That was when a minotaur in heavy armor came in. He looked at you. "This the rookie? Khobo must figure we needed a feminine touch or something."

"Don't you dare say that I'm weak just because I'm a woman, or because I'm human," you said.

"Didn't say that," the minotaur said. "Still, I wonder what that elf saw in you, to recommend you to us. Bozzori, Paladin of Redemption."

"I wonder if they're really as good as that elf claims that they are," said another voice.

Bozzori stepped to the side, revealing a Yuan-Ti, who had a rather large axe strapped to his back.

"Zilis," they said. "Ancestral Guardian Barbarian." They came up to you. "I've heard that you have a strong grip, and a vicious kick, but how sharp is your mind?"

"Good enough to outwit any snake that comes my way," you said.

Zilis grinned. "Let's put it to the test." He placed five gold coins on the bartop. "Five gold says that I can control you. If you can keep yourself under your own control, you take the money. If you fail, you have to kiss me."

You chuckled. "I know a bit about how your Suggestion spell works. It has to sound reasonable for me to agree to do what you want me to do it. How are you going to make me think that kissing you is reasonable?"

Zilis chuckled. "That's simple - I'll let you have the money if you kiss me."

Your eyes bulged as you heard what he said - his Suggestion did seem very Reasonable. You'd get the money if you resisted, or you'd get the money if you gave in. It seemed to be a win-win either way.

12332144.content:
"It's a rather tempting offer," you said.

"You win either way," said Zilis, staring into your eyes. "Resist, and you get the money. Kiss me, and you get the money."

"I would," you said. "Money's always a good incentive."

"It always is," said Zilis. "It mustn't be easy for you. Always having to put on a cold exterior, ignoring the emotional needs of others. Don't you want to be free of having to put on an act, and be true to yourself?"

"Be true to myself?" you asked.

"There's that part of you, who wants to be loved," said Zilis. "A part of you who wants to be held by someone, who will hold you tight, and show you the love you want."

"And what makes you say that?" you asked.

"Because I know."

You looked down, and saw that the snakeman had wrapped his tail around you. You looked up, to see his eyes staring into yours.

"One little kiss?"

"One kiss." You leaned forward, and kissed him.



You blinked, and found yourself looking right at Zilis. "Um, what just happened?"

Zilis chuckled. "You kissed me."

You looked down, and saw Zilis's tail wrapped around you. "What did you do?"

"I simply enhanced the suggestion," said Zilis, as they let go of you. "A tender embrace is very good at getting one willing to accept a kiss."

"You manipulated me," you said. "You did something to make me want to kiss you."

"Yes," said Zilis. "I offered you the money in order for you to kiss me. A win-win either way. After that, a little bit of charm and charisma, and persuasion. Honey is better at attracting flies than vinegar, as the saying goes."

"Why don't I remember what happened?" you asked.

"Because you weren't making those thoughts of your own free will," Zilis said. "Unless a memory recovery spell is used, you won't remember kissing me."

You looked at the coins, and shoved them back to Zilis. "Then keep your money."

Zilis chuckled, and shoved them back to you. "I keep my bargains, even if you don't remember it."

Reluctantly, you picked up the money, and put it into your pouch. "Why did you do that?"

"We're going up against a foe who does play mind games," said Owag. "We're not the only ones after this treasure."

"So, just what is this treasure we're going after?" you asked.

"Does a million in gold sound worth it?" Teoz asked.

Your eyes bulged out at this. "Split thirteen ways? What's that?"

"Over seventy thousand at any rate," said Zeed. "More than enough for anyone to live the way they want to live, at least for a while."

"It's a bit more than just that," said Owag. "According to the stories, it was part of the coffers of a certain cult that worshiped demons. Problem was, said cult crossed certain lines that shouldn't be crossed, least of which was the abduction of children for their sacrificial rituals. Angered a lot of folk for that in particular, so they were systematically captured, put on trial for the crime, and executed. Of course, not all of them were caught, and the survivors hid their treasure."

"So, we're going after treasure that belonged to a bunch of demon-worshipers." You looked over at the Aasimar and Tiefling, and saw them kissing each other. "What about them?"

"They have no issues stealing it," said Berov, as the Loxodon leaned over. "They share no connection to the demon the cult worshiped. Cain is of a different lineage, and Dano's patron is a devil, not a demon."

"But the other one after the treasure, is a different story," said Zilis. "She and her followers do worship this demon, and she will stop at nothing to get the treasure for her group. She has left a trail of bodies across ten countries, and has a significant price on her head in all of them - the bounty upon her head all but rivals that of the amount the treasure is worth."

Roth came over. "Talking about Sharian?"

Teoz nodded. "That's the one."

Roth pulled out a hand crossbow, stretched out his arm, and pulled the trigger, the bolt embedding in a dartboard, in the bullseye. Roth hadn't even looked. "Tell me that we don't need to keep her alive."

"Not according to what I've heard," said Owag. "Just her head is needed."

"Good." Roth turned to walk away, placed his other hand crossbow over his shoulder, and fired. The bolt went through the other one in the dartboard. He still hadn't looked at it.

"He has issues, right?" you asked.

"Sharian killed his sister a couple of years back," said Zeed. "Can't blame him."

"And he's supposed to be the Bard, who is supposed to be able to talk to others," you said. "Kind of expect him to stomp on them."

"He's alright, when his mind isn't on Sharian," said Zilis. "We all have our skills where communication is concerned. "Some are better at persuading, some are better at lying, some can be intimidating, and others, well, they think that they can sing."

"Sing?" you asked.

"Cronk sings, if one can call it that," said Teoz. "However, it's bad enough to make your ears bleed."

"At least it distracted that sea hag long enough for Tovak and Hovak to kill it," said Berov.

Zilis nodded."Well, let's enjoy the food, get a good night's rest, and then, after a good breakfast, we're off." He raised his cup. "For Gold and Glory!"

"For Gold and Glory!" Toasted the rest.

"For Gold and Glory," you muttered. "Is this how they all start?"

"Some of them," said Owag. "Some of them start with a fight from the start."

1233214414.content:
Soon enough, it was time for bed. Much to your surprise, you found that Zeed was sharing a room with you.

"I was expecting to be alone," you said.

"Only six rooms," the Aarakocra said. "Be lucky we rented them prior to arriving. Anyone wanting shelter after us, will either be sleeping in the dining area, or in the barn with the horses. Too be fair, neither option is all that bad. At least we ain't sharing a room with Cain and Dano - they'd keep you up half the night."

"Are they actually lovers?" you asked.

"Only have eyes for one another," said Zeed.

You looked at the bed. "They expect us to share this?"

"Be lucky you're not sharing it with Roth or some of the others," said Zeed. "As you might have noticed, some of them are big and heavy."

"Well, that Roth must eat like a horse," you said.

Zeed chuckled. "Yep, especially if he doesn't have his specific rations. A bit from one of those will keep someone like you and I going for like a week. For him, that's just to keep his stomach content until he gets some actual food."

"Doesn't solve the issue with the bed," you said.

"I wouldn't worry too much about it if I was you anyways," said Zeed. "Putting it bluntly, I'm not interested in mammals for things that involve mating and the like."

"Oh, okay," you said.

Zeed chuckled. "Wouldn't worry about that sort of thing with any of the others either - they'd ask for permission, and they'd make sure to use Protection. That's one of the things we agreed upon when we first started working together. When one is in a strange town, you don't want to get tossed out, or worse, because someone dragged some bar wench into a room, only to find out that not only is she the innkeeper's daughter, said innkeeper has a brother who has a high position in the town guard, and has a cousin who holds influence over the local gangs."

"Sounds like an oddly specific example," you said.

"Happened a few years back," said Zeed. "We'd traveled to this elven town, got there a little late, so there wasn't any room available, beyond the dining area and the barn. During the night, some elf maiden working in one of the rooms was murdered, among other things, and Cronk was blamed, just because he was an orc. Funny thing is, Cronk had quite the alibi - he'd tried to outdrink Berov, and that Loxodon can really hold his liquor - with all he'd drunk, he couldn't even get off the floor, let alone do anything else. Another thing to note, when you've trusted your life to someone more than once, you don't abandon them right away - you do whatever you can to protect them. For any of his faults, Cronk always has our backs whenever we're in a tight spot, and as such, we couldn't do any less for him. Funny thing is, clerics can speak with the dead - Teoz had a nice little chat with the elf maiden. She was able to confirm that Cronk wasn't the one who had harmed her, and, more importantly, revealed that her attacker had been human. That was when Berov did his own checking - Loxodons have very good noses, and figured out who it was, some merchant. Well, whatever else that merchant was, he was good with a knife - mortally injured the innkeeper, causing them to go unconscious, killed some of the other guests, seriously injured the other ones, ran out as the guards were coming, and portrayed us as a pack of murderers. Let me tell you this - anyone can use a crossbow to plant a bolt between someone's eyes, but constantly putting said bolts into their feet and hands, that takes skill. Didn't want to kill any of the guards, again for obvious reasons, but those elves wouldn't have given Cronk or us a fair trial, given what that merchant had claimed we'd done."

"How did you get out of it?" you asked.

"Got Owag to thank for that one," said Zeed. "He talked to the Captain. Pointed out rather clearly that if we were indeed murderers, the wounded guards would all be dead, instead of having issues with their hands and feet. More importantly, he allowed the Captain to enter the inn, to talk to the injured guests. The other guests and the innkeeper backed us up. That Merchant soon had problems bigger than us."

"What happened?" you asked.

"He escaped the guards, but he couldn't outrun the gangs," said Zeed. "One of these gang members could manipulate plants. Seems he was choked to death by some rather thorny vines, and was found hanging from the branch of a tree with said vines growing on it. No one bothered looking into the reasons beyond that."

"Why did he do it?" you asked.

Zeed shrugged. "Doesn't matter. He thought that he could frame our friend, and get us killed. We proved him wrong, and he paid the price."

"I see," you said.

"It's why you can trust us in any situation," said Zeed. "Be it with your life, or your body."

"Alright," you said.

It was then that there was a knock on the door.

Zeed grabbed a dagger, and hid it up their sleeve. "Who is it?"

"It's me!" It was Teoz's voice.

"Who were you with?" Zeed asked.

"Cain and Dano."

Zeed looked at you, pointed to the door, and then, pointed just beside it.

You walked to the door, and opened it, staying to the side, so that Zeed had a clear view of the doorway.

"Come in," said Zeed.

"Dagger up your sleeve," said Teoz's voice.

Zeed pulled the blade out. "One in yours."

You heard something hit the floor, and watched as a dagger was carefully shoved into the room, by cat-like feet.

Zeed nodded. "Enter."

Teoz entered the room, and left the dagger on the floor. "Your turn."

Zeed placed his blade on a table, with it pointing at him. "We good?"

Teoz nodded. "More or less."

Zeed chuckled. "Pick up your blade."

Teoz picked up his dagger. "You yours."

Zeed picked his up. "What's the issue?"

Teoz chuckled. "Make a guess."

"They going at it already?" Zeed asked, with a chuckle.

"Couldn't even let me have a couple hours of sleep before they started up," said Teoz, as he placed his stuff on the floor."I'm not one to judge, but I value my sleep."

"I don't blame you," said Zeed. He looked at you. "You're good to move."

"What was that about?" you asked.

"Had an issue with a doppelganger once," said Teoz. "Luckily for us, we had a Changeling who liked to assume the form of a half-elf when in public. Said doppelganger made the mistake of using that form when the Changeling was using another. It's always interesting when some merchant decided to ask the one who 'looked' like our friend questions to which only we and they should know. Seems that there was a reason that changeling liked that form, and it had to deal with the fact that the half-elf, whose form they'd used, was a murdered friend of theirs, and thus used that form as a way to honor them. Imagine folks surprise when the merchant turned into the very half-elf, and said 'You ain't my friend. I saw them die. Reveal your true form, or I'll kill you!' Bit of an interesting fight, to watch them go at it with daggers, and changing their forms during the fight. Eventually, the one ran, and that's when we asked the other questions to which only we knew the answers to - like the half-elf's name - as we already knew that our friend was a changeling, and we knew the friend's name."

"Since we knew about the doppelganger, we came up with this little ritual, for the old 'Just in case' situations," said Zeed. "You might want to learn it for when you wander around places alone. Might save your life."

"Alright," you said. You looked at the bed. "How are we going to do this?"

"I'll take the wall side," said Teoz. "You get the middle, and Zeed gets the edge. Fairest way I figure, to go by weight and size. You might have issues crawling over me, but I have none crawling over you."

"Alright," you said. "I just hope that there isn't any other issues."

Teoz looked at Zeed. "She knows that she can trust us with her body, right?"

Zeed nodded. "Mentioned it already."

"Good," said Teoz. He looked at you. "Still, if you're ever interested, let me know."

"Are you sure you're a cleric?" you asked.

"Still mortal," said Teoz, with a chuckle. "Besides, Death needs Life in order to exist, and what better way to make sure the cycle continues than to have a few cubs of my own?"

Zeed chuckled. "You are married."

"You know very well that me and that Tabaxi have an open relationship," said Teoz. "I'm not the only male she sleeps with, and she's not the only female I sleep with."

"She is quite the thief," said Zeed. "Good at stealing hearts."

"Well, time for bed," said Teoz. "Still have things to do in the morning."

"Right," you said. "Things to do."

123321441431.content:
Back in training, there'd been separate beds for all trainees. It was against the rules for two people to be in the same bed. This was to prevent certain issues that would be detrimental to training, least of which being Pregnancies, another being Animosity between fellow trainees. Still, in any case, the beds had all been the same general style, and generally only had room for one person. In fact, the beds were all but sized to the person - halflings slept in halfling-sized beds, orcs in orc-sized beds, and so on. In any case, there was no room for two people, especially as the beds had some sort of enchantment that basically kept say two halflings from jumping into an orc-sized bed, because it would become halfling sized.

As it was, you were surprised to see the bed expand to accommodate Teoz, as he laid on it. A moment prior, it had looked like you and Zeed would have had to, all but entangle, just to even fit on it.

"One good thing about the innkeeper," said Teoz. "He at least makes sure that those who do get a bed, will sleep comfortably."

"I suppose so," you said. "I was wondering how we'd fit."

"If you were thinking that we'd be tangled up, could still happen," said Zeed. "At least we'd be tangled up in comfort."

Teoz chuckled. "Small price to pay, for a good bed."

"Um, besides Cain and Dano, is anyone else here, um, into members of the same sex?" you asked.

Zeed chuckled. "Most prefer females, but after doing a job for some time, and there hasn't been any friendly females for a while, sometimes one asks for assistance with that issue."

"Jay was good with that one," said Teoz. "One good thing about a changeling, beyond using their ability to slip into places, is their ability to be the perfect sexual partner when you need one."

You watched as Teoz took his outfit off, leaving him in his loincloth, and you got a good look at his body.

"I see you like muscular guys."

You looked at Zeed, and saw him also wearing little more than his own loincloth. He wasn't as muscular as Teoz, but his wings were interesting.

Zeed chuckled. "The attraction wears off after a while."

"Right," you said, as you took off your own outfit, leaving you in the wrap you used for your breasts to keep them from bouncing around, and well as your own loincloth. "Still, I'd be a liar if I said that Teoz's muscles were not attractive."

Teoz chuckled. "I do get plenty of women. More than Zeed here."

"Like I said, not into mammals," said Zeed. "Still, even I can get a woman when I want one."

"Right," you said. You then got onto the bed. You had to admit, it was very comfortable.........



When you awoke, you found yourself looking at Teoz's chest. You also noticed your arm draped over his side.

"I see you're awake," came Zeed's voice.

You turned, and saw Zeed was dressed.

"Mind getting out of bed?" he asked. "There's some things that Teoz would like to do, but he's too much of a priest to just shove you off of him."

You looked up, to see Teoz staring down at you. There was an amused look on his face.

"Morning," he said.

"Um, sorry," you said, as you moved away from him. "It's just that, um, um...."

"Don't worry about it," said Teoz, as he scooted down to the foot of the bed. "It's only natural to huddle up for warmth."

"One of a thousand things they fail to teach at the Academy," said Zeed. "Another being that few Adventurers remain a Virgin for more than a few months."

You looked at Zeed. "Seriously?"

Zeed chuckled. "There's a reason we all carry Protection."

"Another thing that they don't teach you, is how to respond to the death of a friend," said Teoz. "Or how to respond to your first kill."

"You mentioned a Changeling that was in the party," you said. "What happened to them?"

"Let's just say that there was a reason we talked to Khobo about picking out our thirteenth member," said Zeed.

"What happened?" you asked.

"It's like this," Teoz said, as he got his outfit on. "Jay -"

"Jay got caught up in a Cursed Item issue," said Teoz. "Long story short, there is this village that had a Champion. Good fella actually, protected the village from those who'd do harm to it. Slight issue, he fell for a pretty woman, who poisoned him. That woman was Sharian. Sharian had summoned a demon to attack that village. The Champion had a special sword, of the sort of material that seriously messes up a demon's day. Issue is, only the Champion could wield it, as it was bonded to him. Jay thought that they could trick the sword into accepting them as a user."

"Did it work?" you asked.

"Not exactly," said Zeed. "The sword was one of those intelligent weapons, with powers of its own. It knew full well that Jay wasn't the Champion. It only allowed Jay to use it, if Jay was willing to take the Champion's place as the village's protector."

"I take it they accepted," you said.

Teoz nodded. "Whatever else one might have said about Jay, they were at least willing to pay the price. He can't leave that village, unless the villagers move, the sword requires him elsewhere, or the sword finds a more suitable replacement."

"So, then why did you ask for me anyways?" you asked. "I mean, you have a Paladin, a turtle whose shell's almost as good as full plate armor, and other folks who'd be good in a fight. So, why me?"

Zeed chuckled. "Because sometimes, someone who doesn't use magic, can take a blow, and doesn't scare people away with their looks, is useful to have. In some places, folks like me, Teoz, and the others, we look rather odd, and might not get any assistance. Humans however, you're all over. You can at least get shopkeepers to sell you things and buy stuff from us, if they think that you're in charge of us. Likewise, you can get us rooms in the inn, and not in the barn. Also, those who give out Reward Money might pay extra for what they think is a pretty face."

"Really?" you ask.

"Hard to get information unless folks are willing to talk to you," said Teoz. "If anything else, you're not bad looking. Of course, if you need help with the persuading, or if need be, deception and intimidation, we can help you practice those skills."

"So, you don't need me for my fighting skills, but mainly so that folks will talk to at least someone in the group?" you asked.

Zeed nodded. "Sword swingers are easy to find. Talkers however, not so easy. A pretty human woman, tends to have an edge at any rate, especially one that can swing a sword too!"

Teoz chuckled. "Like I said, if you need help with the social skills, we can all help - we'll see to it you'll have the skills to lie, scare, and persuade, as need be."

"Alright," you said. "I guess I can do that."

"Good," said Zeed. "I'll be downstairs." He left the room.

12332144143154.content:
It had been a rather long day by the time the group came to a stop. From the time you left the inn, until Owag deemed it was good enough to stop, you reckoned you'd traveled about thirty miles in the space of eight hours. You were near a relatively sheltered area, with a stream nearby.

"Looks safe enough," said Owag. "Enough light to locate some additional dry wood for a fire for supper."

"I'll take the mounts," said Roth, once the packs were taken off. "Berov - does that trunk of yours say if that stream's safe enough to drink from?"

The loxodon chuckled. Then, he sniffed. "Safe enough, but if you fancy a swim, do so downstream from where we get any drinking water."

"Don't need to drink horse piss again," Cronk muttered.

"That was only once!" Roth called back, as he took the mounts. "And it wasn't mine!"

Bozzori chuckled. The minotaur looked at you. "Rookie mistake. We've all made them."

"Just make sure that they don't get you killed," said Tovak. The hobgoblin took out a woodcutting ax and passed it to you, then got out another. "We're on wood duty."

You looked at him. "What about the others?"

"Everyone has to do something," said Owag. "Since you're the newest, you get wood duty tonight. Teaches you how to locate your way back."

You watched as the rest were doing one thing or another, clearing the area of large rocks, logs, setting up a fire pit, as well as a sleeping area, although Zeed had flown up into a tree, and seemed to be keeping a lookout.

Tovak placed his hand on your shoulder. "Come on. I know humans don't see too good in the dark, and neither do some of the others."



You followed the hobgoblin into the woods, until he found a fallen tree.

"What do you think?" he asked.

"I don't know," you said. "I thought that we were going to cut down trees."

"Bad idea there," said Tovak. "Place might have pixies living in the live ones, and don't get me started on dryads and others of that sort of nature. Piss off the wrong one, you end up dead at best, or you get turned into a tree at worst, being fully aware of everything, yet being unable to do anything. Saw it happen once."

"Was it one of the group?" you asked.

"We're usually smart enough not to piss off the wrong people," said Tovak. "It's one thing to have enemies, but never anger someone you know you cannot defeat."

"Then how do Adventurers defeat powerful enemies?" you asked, as you lifted up one end of the fallen tree. "I mean, there's stories of Heroes defeating monsters that could easily kill a normal man. How does that work?"

"Behind every Hero is a Team," said Tovak, as he picked up a section further down. "As far as an orc is concerned, Cronk gets credit whenever our group is mentioned in Orc territory. Zeed could be the one who slit a giant's throat to make sure that it was dead, but, because Cronk's arrows were in the giant's organs, orcs will claim that Cronk killed the giant. Likewise, if you kill a hydra in Leonin territory, Teoz gets the credit because he used his magic to injure it."

"Sounds like it's stupid," you said, as the two of you started walking. "All that work, and no credit."

"Yes, but if I kill a demon that was destroying the land, in a human kingdom, you'd get the credit, just because you were spotted trying to fight it," said Tovak. "You could have done next to no damage, got thrown around like a rat shaken by a terrier, and I do all the hard work of killing it, only for you to get all the credit. Does that sound fair to you?"

"No," you said.

"Yet, that's how this thing works," said Tovak. "You do something, but get no credit. You do little, yet take all the credit. The one who got the credit might say, 'Actually, they were the one to kill the monster,' only for this claim to be ignored by whomever it was told to."

"So, what does one do in such a situation?" you asked.

Tovak chuckled. "Don't go bragging about it. Don't say that you did it, don't say you didn't. Just keep eating the food on your plate, and enjoying your drink."

"What if they knock the plate off, and call you a coward?" you asked.

"Order another plate of food," said Tovak. "Never make a hostile reaction, unless you have to."

"What if they try to grab you?" you asked, recalling the tavern incident two years back.

"Grab their hand before they grab you," said Tovak. "After that, to shove them back would be the best thing, but you'd probably end up in a fight anyways."

"What if you do have to fight?" you asked.

"Don't pull out a weapon, or use a spell, unless you have to," said Tovak. "Unconscious fools recover. Dead ones, don't."

"And if they pull out a weapon?" you asked.

"Disarm them if possible," said Tovak. "Failing that, remove the hand from the wrist, in a clean cut if possible. Makes reattaching easier."

"What if they still won't stop?" you asked.

"Sheath your weapons, and head to a temple of healing," said Tovak. "They'll need to visit there anyways."

"So, basically, avoid fighting whenever possible?" you asked.

"General idea," said Tovak.

"What if there's no choice, and it's them or you?" you asked.

"Be the one still standing," said Tovak.

"I'm surprised that, aside from Zilis's Suggestion spell, you've not done any actual testing of my training," you said.

Tovak chuckled. "Worry about that one later. Also, just because you've made it to the top at the Academy, it means nothing to an Adventurer with ten or more years experience. The guys at the Academy train you by the book. We'll train you by practicality."

"Um, what about literature?" you asked.

"You like romance-type stories?" Tovak asked.

"No, but my teacher did say that it was good to read," you said.

Tovak chuckled. "Useful for when there's nothing to do. Occupies the mind a bit. Share you my book, or one of the others will if you ask them. We all have some."

"What are they about?" you ask.

"Depends," said Tovak. "Cain and Dano like those romance stories though."

You chuckle at this. "Who would have thought?"



Soon enough, you and Tovak got near the camp, when....

123321441431541.content:
It happened quickly. A flash of movement, and next thing you knew, you were facedown on the ground. You tried to get up, when your assailant placed their claws on your throat, and pressed. The message was clear - move, and you'd die. You stopped struggling. A sack was placed over your head, and you were tied up. Then, you were thrown over, you assume, their shoulders, before they began moving. Any attempt by yourself to move was met with claws touching your skin, and some sort of growling warning. Any attempt to speak was met with similar. For a moment, you wondered about Tovak - was the hobgoblin in a similar predicament, or was he dead, or worse yet, behind this!

After, you guess, half an hour, you were tossed onto the ground. You listened to your captor talk to some others. The language was harsh, and full of beastial sounds, and seemed to be predatory. When you attempted to communicate, pressure from your captor's claws was applied, again, seeming to be a warning. As for attempts to escape your bonds, that resulted in them placing their foot on your back, and pressing down, hard. You then smelled something - smoke. You also heard the bubbling of water.

That was when the rope around your hands and feet was undone, but again, claws were applied to your skin, giving you a clear message.

"You speak now," said a gruff, and unfriendly voice. "Why you trespass on sacred land?"

"We were just setting up camp," you said.

"You admit guilt," the speaker said. "Death to trespass on this land."

"I didn't know," you said.

"No excuse," the voice said. "Human stew taste good."

You stiffened at this. You'd heard about such folk. However, you kept silent. If you could get a knife, maybe you could escape.

"Clothes!"

Strong arms and hands soon stripped you of your clothing, and you were tied up once more, face down on the ground.

"Seasonings!"

That was when something was applied to your back. You weren't sure what it was, but it was warm, and they rubbed it into your body. It would have felt good, if not for the fact that they were preparing you for the pot. There was a fruity smell to it, which would have been a nice perfume, but for the situation. Then you were flipped over, and more of this stuff was applied. Again, it would have been nice, but for the situation. For a moment, you were actually glad you had the sack over your head. Then, a couple of them lifted you up, carried you over, and, rather carefully, placed you in something that, not only had warm water, but felt more like a bathtub than the inside of a large pot.

"What kind of cooking pot is this?" you asked.

"A bathtub," said a familiar voice.

That was when you heard the splitting of the rope around your wrists, and you found yourself able to move your hands, and you managed to remove the sack from your head, and you saw Teoz grinning, a few feet from you, with a dagger in his hand.

"What was all that about?" you asked.

"Little bit of hygiene and a lesson," said Teoz. "You haven't had a bath in a few days, and that stench could give us away to the wrong people."

You chuckled nervously. "Right. And the lesson?"

"Never assume the camp is safe," said Teoz. "Better to assume that someone killed us all while you were gone, only to find that everything is alright, than to assume everything is fine, only to get taken captive by a pack of slavers or cannibals."

"I see that," you said, as you removed the rope from your wrists, and began working on those around your ankles. "Surprised you have a bathtub."

"Got a few actually," said Teoz. "We all have a few Bags of Holding, so getting at least a couple of bathtubs was possible." He then tossed to you a hand towel, the kind used for washing one's body.

"Still, why?" you asked, as you began scrubbing, also realizing that you were coated in citrus-scented soap.

"Because only poor fools take baths in cold streams," said Owag, as the tortle came up, draping a bath towel on a branch, as well as a clean shirt, pants, and undergarments. "After all, when one has access to money, getting a bathtub is easy. Also, when one has means to make boiled water, it's merely a matter of practice to figure out a good ratio of cold stream water to that of boiled, to make it warm enough to bath in without cooking yourself."

"That, and a few of them wanted to double-check their human female anatomy," said Zeed, as he came over with some cut fruit on a tray, and attached it to the tub. "Some fresh fruit, and your sword - always useful to have nearby." He also set your sword by the tub. "Some were under the impression that they had six tits."

"Bozzori?" Teoz asked.

"That bull already knew," said Zeed. "It was the other bull that guessed wrong."

Teoz chuckled. "Thought the elephant knew better. Guess he forgot."

You had to chuckle at this, as you grabbed an apple slice. "I was part of a bet between them?"

Zeed chuckled. "You'd be surprised at what we'd bet on. Just don't bet more than you can pay."

"What was that language you were speaking anyways?" you asked. "Never heard anything like it."

"Little of Leonin, little of Orcish, bit of Goblinoid, some Primordial, Dwarvish, and Minotaur," said Zeed. "Touch of Elvish too."

"Quite literally, each word is from another language from the previous ones," said Owag. "Trick is not to use a language understood by outsiders. Mostly, it's for fun, as it can be annoying to carry on a serious conversation using bits and pieces from five or more languages."

"I suppose it would," you said. You then looked at Teoz. "Got something for my hair?"

The Leonin chuckled. "I do. Works better in a warmed up liquid form, like that soap I rubbed all over you."

You blush at the memory. "Your wife must like your hands."

"She does," Teoz said, as he got behind you. He then put something into your hair, and began carefully running their claws all over your scalp.

"If you ever get tired of being a cleric, you ought to work in a bathhouse," you said. "Your hands feel good."

"You're welcome," Teoz. "As it was, I was something of a body cleaner."

"Really?" you asked. "Surprised that the God of Death would hold services in a bathhouse."

"More like cleaned them in preparation for getting dressed for their funeral," said Teoz. "There's reasons folks burn incense as part of funeral rites."

"Why did you become an Adventurer then?" you asked. "Priests make good money, right?"

"I had a vision, one that involved both the God of Death that I serve, as well as a Hero that my people tell stories about," said Teoz. "I was asked to, not only bring honor to my people, but to explain to good things about Death."

"That one might be tricky," you said.

Teoz chuckled. "Perhaps. But, I have faith. Being approachable helps."

"I suppose it would," you said.

"Well, that should take care of your hair," said Teoz, as he wetted his hands in the bath water. "Stuff washes out easily, once you duck your head under, and your hair will have a nice shine to it, and be in good condition overall."

"Well, thanks for the bath," you said. "Just don't jump me like that again."

"Take one at least every other day when we're near a stream, and we won't make you take one," said Zeed. "No promises about jumping you though."

"You need to learn one way or another," said Owag. He pointed at a group of bushes. "We're on the other side of those, when you're done. Yell out if there's any issues. We'll have supper ready soon."

"And if I don't yell out if there's trouble?" you asked.

Zeed pointed at the tree he'd been using as a lookout. "If you don't mind me looking at you from time to time, I have a good view of this spot."

"Well, as you say, you're not into mammals," you said.

Zeed chuckled. "That's correct."

With that, the three left, leaving you to enjoy your bath.
123321441431541.title: Surprise Lesson, and a Bath

1233214414315411.content:
The bath had been nice and peaceful. You had to admit, it was good to get cleaned up. As you got dressed, you looked up at Zeed's perch. The way he was positioned had been somewhat behind you, and you hadn't always been able to keep an eye on him as a result. Then, there was the others - again, you had been unable to keep an eye on them for obvious reasons. As you finished putting your sword belt on, you checked your sword, and carefully walked around the brush separating you from the camp, trying to not make a lot of noise beyond that of just the usual types of noise, as you knew that Zeed, or rather, the one that looked like him, was possibly watching you. Eventually, you got to an area, where you could see the entire camp, while staying somewhat hidden, or at least looked like you were just catching your breath at any rate, your main hand carefully near your sword handle, just in case.

Zilis turned his head, and saw you. The Yuan-Ti waved you over.

However, you stayed put. After all, for all you knew, a group of Doppelgangers had showed up, killed them silently, and replaced them.

Zilis grinned, and started laughing. "She's getting smarter!"

"Come on in," said Owag. "You at least got the right idea of waiting to make sure."

"I didn't want to get tackled so soon after a bath," you said, coming in, hand still near the sword handle.

"She's getting wiser too," said Berov. "She's prepared to draw her weapon in case she got fooled by a potential trap."

"As I stated," you said, as you sat down on a log. "I didn't fancy taking another bath."

"Good enough for me," said Zeed from his perch.

"What were you going to do if I just walked in?" you asked, as you accepted a hot bowl of stew from Tovak.

"Sleep spell," said Bozzori. "You'd gone to bed without supper."

"I see," you said. "Never assume that the camp is safe?"

"Right," said Hovak. "Also, while on that note, never assume anyone coming into the camp is whom they claim to be."

"I've heard the story about Jed and the doppelganger," you said.

"That's why," said Roth.

"Always learn from someone else's mistakes," said Bozzori. "Especially if they proved to be fatal ones."

Owag chuckled. "At least you're learning."

You were about to take a bite of the stew, when you noticed that Zilis was still watching you. "Did you put the stew into the bowls before they got passed out?"

"I did," the Yuan-Ti said.

"Um, did you put something extra into my bowl by chance?" you asked.

Zilis laughed again. "She's catching on!" He turned to Tovak. "Pay up."

"What's in my bowl?" you asked.

"Tovak gave you a bowl of mud and gravel, on with an illusion spell on it," said Owag. "Toss out the contents, and we'll wash it later."

You flung the contents into the brush. "Almost ate a mud pie," you muttered.

Owag got up, filled another bowl, and gave it to you. "At least it wasn't poison. One guy that tried to kill us, found out that Yuan-Ti make terrible food tasters. Zilis gave us clean plates, and then poisoned the one meant for him, which our foe made the foolish mistake of taking for himself."

"I'm good at lying and sneaky-type stuff," said Zilis. "Typical things associated with my kind."

"Hope you don't poison friends," you said, as you took a bite. The stew was delicious.

"Not unless they ask me too," Zilis said, softly.

You looked up at this, and you could swear that there was a tear in the snake-man's eye, which they quickly wiped away.

info.description:
You were born a nobody, a measly farmer living in poverty with your parents. But even from a young age, you always dreamed of becoming a Hero. Heroes and Heroines are like the celebrities of this world, admired and loved by the public, raking in the gold and swooned over by fanboys\girls. You swore that the day you came of age, you would join the Hero's Academy and make a name for yourself. Well, that day has arrived. Biding your parents farewell, you set out with only the clothes on your back, a small pouch of gold coins and a dagger for protection. You journey to the capital to begin your new life.

How This Works

At the end of the first chapter, you shall select your character's gender, followed by your class type and your sub-class. From there, it's all up to you where your adventures will lead you. Will you climb the ranks of the Guild and become the greatest Hero who ever lived? Or will you fail and fall into obscurity, your name forever lost to history?

Rules:

1. This is meant to be a sort of parody of old school role-playing games like D&D and things like that. Try to add some humor here and there .
2. If you're going to kill the main character, don't make it overly gory or descriptive. Also, let the story get to a decent length first.
3. All chapters are to be a minimum of 3 to 5 paragraphs long.

I reserve the right to add or edit rules as needed. Hope you enjoy the story!
